events.event_description: Wind generation set a new record of 47.7 TWh in April 2024, exceeding coal-fired generation for two consecutive months (March and April 2024) for the first time in U.S. history.
events.citation: Electricity generation from wind established a new record in the United States in April, and wind generation exceeded coal-fired generation in both March and April, data from our July 2024 Monthly Energy Review show.

events.event_description: Wind installations in the U.S. produced 45.9 TWh of electricity in March 2024, surpassing coal-fired generation of 38.4 TWh.
events.citation: Wind installations in the United States produced 45.9 terawatthours (TWh) of electricity in March 2024, compared with 38.4 TWh from coal-fired power plants.

events.event_description: U.S. installed wind power capacity reached 150.1 GW while coal capacity declined to 177.1 GW.
events.citation: Installed wind power generating capacity has increased substantially in the United States over the last 25 years, growing from 2.4 gigawatts (GW) in 2000 to 150.1 GW in April 2024. By contrast, a substantial number of coal plants have retired over the past 25 years, with total coal capacity falling from 315.1 GW in 2000 to 177.1 GW by April 2024.

events.event_description: Operators plan to add 7.1 GW of new wind capacity in the United States in 2024.
events.citation: Operators expect 7.1 GW of wind capacity to come online in the United States in 2024, according to our July Monthly Energy Review.

events.event_description: Plans announced to retire 2.8 GW of coal-fired capacity in 2024, following 22.3 GW of retirements over the past two years.
events.citation: After 22.3 GW of U.S. coal-fired electric generating capacity retired over the past two years, operators plan to slow coal retirements in 2024. Operators plan to retire 2.8 GW of coal-fired capacity in 2024, data from our July Monthly Energy Review show.
